Attached Technical Assistance Report  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 52300-001 
November 2018 
 
 
 
Republic of Uzbekistan: Sustainable Energy Access 
– Distribution Network Modernization Program  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  program,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

PROGRAM PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The program preparatory transaction technical assistance (TA) is necessary to: (i) conduct 
technical  due  diligence  on  the  distribution  network  modernization  program  soundness, 
expenditure and financing, and program results and links with disbursement to determine the 
degree to which the results-based lending (RBL) program will achieve its results; (ii) examine the 
government and Uzbekenergo’s monitoring and evaluation systems, the fiduciary systems, and 
the environmental and social safeguards systems; and (iii) prepare the proposed RBL program 
design,  and  (vi)  assess  and  enhance  the  capacity  of  Uzbekenergo  to  support  program 
implementation and achieve results.

C.  Cost Estimate and Financing Plan 
 
2.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000 equivalent, of which $750,000 equivalent will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The 
government will provide $50,000 in the form of counterpart staff, office facilities and other in-kind 
counterpart support. The detailed cost estimates are presented in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
4.  The TA is anticipated to require 15 person-months (p-m) of international and 24 p-m of 
national consulting services for a total of 13 consultants to be engaged using individual consultant 
selection following ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated  project  administration  instructions  and  staff  instructions.  Individual  consultants, 
through firms if applicable, will be hired in view of the short processing lead time for the RBL 
program preparation. Advance contracting will be used to recruit the TA consultants under an 
output-based  (lump-sum) contracts  wherever  possible.  Depending  on actual  project  needs, 
resource persons may also be required. Any additional consultant not envisaged at this time will 
be recruited individually and will be additionally funded by TA facility upon approval of the facility. 
The consultants will report to ADB and coordinate with Uzbekenergo and the key implementing 
agencies of the government on the substance and timing of the TA outputs and activities (Table 
A3.1). Key findings and recommendations of the TA will be discussed in final workshops and a 
national workshop.

5.  The outline terms of reference for the program preparatory TA consultants are described 
in paras. 6 to 14.  
 
6.  (Result-based) Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist (international, 3 person-month) 
The expert will (i) help the government design the multi-year program, including a results 
framework and an expenditure framework; (ii) develop the RBL program design including the 
design  and  monitoring  framework  and  a  separate  results  framework  and  an  expenditure 
framework; (iii) finalize DLIs and DLIs’ verification protocols; and (iv) propose the disbursement 
schedule. The expert will assess the government program’s monitoring and evaluation systems 
and identify gaps that may affect program implementation and results monitoring and evaluation. 
Based on the risk assessment, the program action plan, and the gaps identified, the consultants 
will develop a monitoring and evaluation system for the RBL program. The consultants will also 
build the capacity of the government and implementing agencies in understanding RBL. The 
expert will be assisted by a national Economist (design, results, monitoring and evaluation, 3 
person-months)  
 
7.  Power Distribution Engineer (international, 4 person-months; and national, 4 person-
months) The experts will examine the government’s distribution modernization program and its 
implementation arrangement for identification of gaps; and develop a modernization master 
concept  incorporating  international  best  practices.  The  experts  will  assess the government 
program’s adequacy and economic efficiency, results and links with disbursements under the RBL 
program, expenditures and financing, and implementation arrangements. Necessary measures 
and actions to be taken to strengthen the government investment program will be identified for 
inclusion in the program action plan and in capacity development TA design, with clear results 
and monitoring mechanisms.  
 
8.  Financial  Management  Specialist  (international,  3  person-months;  and  national  3 
person-months) The experts will assess the government program’s adequacy and economic 
efficiency, results and links with disbursements under the RBL program, expenditures and 
financing, and implementation arrangements. Necessary measures and actions to be taken to 
strengthen the government investment program will be identified for inclusion in the program 
action  plan.  The  experts  will  further  assess  the  program’s  fiduciary  systems  and  provide 
reasonable assurance for the appropriate use of program funds. The key outputs are program 
expenditure and financing assessment; fiduciary systems assessment; financial management 
systems assessment for Uzbekenergo; and risk mitigation plan, including capacity development 
activities for inclusion in the program action plan and the piggyback TA design with clear results 
and monitoring measures.  
 
9.  Procurement Specialist (international 1 person-month; national, 2 person-months). The 
expert will conduct program’s procurement system assessment and prepare risk mitigation plan 
as integral part of fiduciary assessment. The consultants will also prepare the program integrated 
risk mitigation and provide inputs to fiduciary assessment and integrated risk mitigation plan.  
 
10.  Safeguard Specialist (Environment) (international and national, 2 person-months each). 
The expert will assess the program environment safeguard system and conduct a climate change 
mitigation assessment. The assessments, in accordance with RBL guidance, will develop action 
plans to address the gaps and recommend measures for using the national environment and 
climate change regulations and systems in accordance with the principles of ADB’s Safeguards 
Policy Statement (2009). The expert will carefully examine the existing Uzbekenergo’s safeguards 
management systems, especially the waste management such as PCB and chemicals, and 
consolidate social safeguard system assessment into a program safeguard system assessment.

11.  Safeguard Specialist (Social) (national, 2 person-months). The expert will assess the 
program social safeguard system. The assessments, in accordance with RBL guidance, will 
develop action plans to address the gaps and recommend measures for using the national land 
acquisition and resettlement regulations and systems in accordance with the principles of ADB’s 
Safeguards  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  expert  will  carefully  examine  the  existing 
Uzbekenergo’s safeguards management systems and provide inputs to a program safeguard 
system assessment.  
 
12.  Social Development Specialist (Gender) (national, 3 person-months). The expert will 
prepare  poverty  and  social  analysis  using  participatory  methods  to  assess  the  type  and 
significance of the project impacts on the poor, women, and any other vulnerable group. This will 
also build on the existing work done. The consultant will assist in sector assessment and program 
review to bring out impact of program by women. The consultant will prepare (i) gender analysis 
report, (ii) collect the sex-disaggregated data (including data on local women-led businesses and 
household level information) needed to support proposed gender indicators and (iii) suggestions 
for other possible DLI related gender targets. The recommendations will be included in the 
program results framework and the program monitoring and evaluation systems.  
 
13.  All consultants engaged under the TA will assist the project team in reviewing and 
consolidating the risks identified and measures and actions recommended by the assessments 
indicated in paras. 6–12 and develop a risk mitigation plan with clear results and monitoring 
mechanisms. All consultants will also contribute to the design of a proposed piggyback TA. To 
manage and coordinate the administrative and contractual matters, a national TA and contracts 
coordinator (5 person-months) will be hired under the TA.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.   Joint-Stock Company Uzbekenergo (Uzbekenergo) will be the executing agency for the 
TA. A program management unit (PMU) will be established under Uzbekenergo to manage the 
overall  program,  including  the  RBL  Program.  The  program  manager  has  been  appointed. 
Uzbekenergo  has  allocated  and  will  continue  to  allocate  sufficient  resources  and  qualified 
personnel as required for the program. The PMU will closely work with the TA consultants.  
 
3.  Uzbekenergo will assist the TA consultants in data gathering, preliminary analysis, and 
report writing and liaising with other government ministries and agencies. Uzbekenergo will also 
provide and make available to the consultants, free of charge, the counterpart staff, office space 
with  furniture  and  equipment,  documents  and  information,  and  organizational  support  for 
seminars, meetings and site surveys as reasonably required by the TA consultants to carry out 
their tasks. The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A3.4.
